Articles.Content:
An Atlas V 501 carrying an X-37 uncrewed spaceplane and a number of secondary payloads is set to launch about 45 minutes from the time of this post. Coverage by ULA is [here](http://www.ulalaunch.com/webcast.aspx), and coverage by the planetary society (who operate one of the secondary payloads) is [here](http://sail.planetary.org/missioncontrol).

- - - Updated - - -

ULA's [webcast](http://www.ulalaunch.com/webcast.aspx) has started.
I'm surprised they are still moving it into position this close to launch, is this normal?
That's a recap, they did that yesterday.
Wow, bad timing on my part then, whoops.
Go for launch. Less than four minutes now.
This mission, OTV-4 will be the second flight of X-37B#2. It will test new ion engines in space as well as conduct material study's for NASA. The AirForce mission is classified.

Nice launch!

Just wondering why does the x-37B have an off centre thruster on the back?

Well, she's up. And in a post launch promotional video, they declare that the X-37B is the FIRST unmanned vehicle to land on a runway.

Um... BURAN?

- - - Updated - - -

Love Steve's Space Shuttle tie! ![:D](//kerbal-forum-uploads.s3.us-west-2.amazonaws.com/emoticons/default_k_cheesy.gif)

> 
> Well, she's up. And in a post launch promotional video, they declare that the X-37B is the FIRST unmanned vehicle to land on a runway.
> Um... BURAN?
> 
> - - - Updated - - -
> 
> Love Steve's Space Shuttle tie! ![:D](//kerbal-forum-uploads.s3.us-west-2.amazonaws.com/emoticons/default_k_cheesy.gif)

Just like Musk declares the FH has the most carrying capabilities since the Saturn V... Energia...

- - - Updated - - -

> 
> Nice launch!
> Just wondering why does the x-37B have an off centre thruster on the back?

Maybe the weight internally is off balance so the engines position is changed to correct it.

> 
> Nice launch!
> Just wondering why does the x-37B have an off centre thruster on the back?

If you want symmetrical thrust the thrust vector has to pass through the CoM

> 
> If you want symmetrical thrust the thrust vector has to pass through the CoM

I think it is because of the solar panels that stick out during orbit. They are off to the side so the thruster offsets that i think.

There might also be some requirements because of internal hardware + plumbing / hull structure / connection to the rocket's upper stage that prevent the engine from being centered. Afterwards, as long as the engine is lined up with the COM, we're in space ^^ spacecraft orientation relatively to the engines doesn't matter - as long as your engine is thrusting in the correct direction ![:P](//kerbal-forum-uploads.s3.us-west-2.amazonaws.com/emoticons/default_k_tongue.gif)
